narrative.title: 46Th Infantry Division - 1943Q1
narrative.situation: British infantry_division deployed in North Africa during 1943Q1.
narrative.objectives: British First Army infantry division for Tunisia Campaign. Arrived January 1943, immediately committed to defensive operations in difficult northern Tunisia terrain. Held critical sectors at Sedjenane and Hunt's Gap against German offensives (February-March 1943). Participated in final offensive operations (April-May 1943) leading to Axis surrender.
narrative.axis_objective: Hold current positions and prevent Allied breakthrough.
narrative.allied_objective: Advance and neutralize Axis defensive positions.

weather.terrain: Northern Tunisia - hilly terrain with river valleys (Sedjenane valley), mixed agricultural land and rocky hills. More restrictive than Western Desert. Beja sector features extensive hill positions. Better cover but channelized movement.

air_support.note: No theater air summary available for this quarter

special_rules: Fresh division from UK with full modern equipment
Three well-trained Territorial Army brigades (Hampshire, mixed counties, Sherwood Foresters)
Experienced defensive operations in restrictive hill terrain
Effective artillery support (substantial fire at Hunt's Gap)
Combined operations with Churchill tanks, commandos, and French units
Adaptability: shifted 100 miles south on 2 April for new offensive operations

environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia - hilly terrain with river valleys (Sedjenane valley), mixed agricultural land and rocky hills. More restrictive than Western Desert. Beja sector features extensive hill positions. Better cover but channelized movement.
